channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Missiles Strike Ukraine; Moscow Blames Kyiv for Blasts at 2 Bases in Russia
item.description: Hours after blasts were reported at two military bases deep inside Russia, Ukraine said that Moscow had launched a new barrage of airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A neighborhood in the Kyiv suburb of Irpin on Sunday.

item.title: Cyril Ramaphosa Unlikely to Face Impeachment in South Africa
item.description: Leaders of the governing African National Congress said they opposed holding an impeachment hearing for President Cyril Ramaphosa over a scandal involving cash stolen from a couch at his game farm.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa after a meeting of the African National Congress in Johannesburg on Monday to discuss his fate.

item.title: What to Know About Iran’s Morality Police
item.description: A top official suggested over the weekend that the unit, responsible for enforcing the country’s strict dress code, had been shut down, though there has not been any government confirmation.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: An Iranian woman gestured while talking to morality policemen during a crackdown to enforce the Islamic dress code, in Tehran, Iran, in 2007.

item.title: Putin Signs Law Banning Expressions of LGBTQ Identity in Public
item.description: The law makes it illegal to spread “propaganda” about “nontraditional sexual relations” in all media, including social, advertising and movies.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Authorities blocking a L.G.B.T.Q. rally in Saint Petersburg, Russia, in 2019.

item.title: Brussels Terrorist Attack Trial Opens, Reviving Painful Memories
item.description: The proceedings against 10 men linked to the 2016 bombings at an airport and a subway station are the largest ever organized in Belgium and are expected to last up to eight months.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Masked police stood guard on Monday as lawyers spoke with defendants in a specially designed glass box during the start of the trial for the 2016 Brussels attacks.

item.title: China Stems Wave of Protest, but Ripples of Resistance Remain
item.description: Students, residents, lawyers and workers are still challenging the country’s Covid-19 restrictions, even though the intensity of the political chants has been dialed back.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che, Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and Joy Dong
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A demonstration in Beijing last month against strict coronavirus measures. The recent unrest has been the boldest and most widespread in China since the pro-democracy movement of 1989.

item.title: China Protests Raise Hopes of Activists Abroad
item.description: People opposing Beijing over issues like Hong Kong, Taiwan or the persecution of Uyghurs see the moment as an opportunity to find common cause.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and John Liu
item.media:description: Students lighting candles last week on the campus of the Chinese University of Hong Kong to show solidarity with protesters in mainland China.

item.title: Photos: Indonesia’s Mount Semeru Erupts, Displacing Nearly 2,000
item.description: When the volcano erupted late last year, more than 50 people were killed, and hundreds more were injured.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of Mount Semeru from Kajar Kuning village in Lumajang, Indonesia, on Monday. The volcano erupted early Sunday.

item.title: Sudan Military and Pro-Democracy Coalition Sign Peace Deal
item.description: The agreement, which was boycotted by some political forces, comes more than a year after a coup that scuttled the country’s transition to democratic rule.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Sudanese demonstrators protesting in the capital, Khartoum, in August against a military coup that deepened the country’s political and economic turmoil.

item.title: ‘Important Step’ Toward Addressing Toxic Legacy of Huge Mine
item.description: Residents of the Papua New Guinea have accused the mining company Rio Tinto of violating their human rights by despoiling the land where they live.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Human Rights Law Center, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Theonila Roka Matbob, a local landowner, near the shuttered Panguna mine pit in Bougainville, Papua New Guinea, in 2019.

item.title: Skyrocketing Prices in Turkey Hurt Families and Tarnish Erdogan
item.description: Annual inflation is around its highest level in decades, devaluing salaries and devouring savings less than a year before President Recep Tayyip Erdogan runs for re-election.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A currency exchange office in Istanbul. With the Turkish lira’s fall, the minimum wage is now worth less than $300 a month.

item.title: Iran Has Abolished Morality Police, Official Suggests, After Months of Protests
item.description: The move, which the government did not confirm, might be a concession to the protest movement that erupted after the death of a young woman in the custody of the morality police.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Tehran in October. The protests ignited by the death of Mahsa Amini have grown to encompass the entire range of discontents with Iran’s rulers.

item.title: In War, Ukrainians Forage for Mushrooms in Forests With Mines
item.description: These misty and damp parts of the country have long beckoned to mushroom hunters with the promise of plenty, but now peril, too, lies beneath the earth’s surface.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Polish mushroom, a kind of porcini, growing on the forest floor in the Bucha district of Ukraine.

item.title: Ramaphosa Vows to Fight Impeachment Report and Seek Re-election
item.description: The South African president had considered resigning after Parliament released a report last week accusing him of violating his oath of office by obscuring details about a 2020 robbery at his game farm.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa said on Saturday that he would not resign in the face of a parliamentary inquiry.

item.title: Despite Sanctions, Russian Cruise Missiles Were Made Recently
item.description: Weapons investigators in Kyiv found that at least one Russian Kh-101 cruise missile used in widespread attacks there on Nov. 23 had been made no earlier than October.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russia attacked the port of the southern Ukrainian city of Kherson in November.

item.title: Putin Inspects Crimean Bridge Partially Destroyed By Explosion
item.description: When the bridge opened in 2018, it was a powerful symbol of the connection the Kremlin was attempting to forge between Russia and Crimea, a Ukrainian region illegally annexed by Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: This photograph released by Russian state media shows Russian President Vladimir V. Putin at the Kerch Strait Bridge on Monday.

item.title: The End of a Presidential Launchpad
item.description: Democrats stripped Iowa of its first-in-the-nation status.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Jimmy Carter in Des Moines in 1976.

item.title: He returned a dazed soldier to the Russians. Ukraine calls it treason.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Watchmen at the junction in Kherson, Ukraine, where they captured a disoriented Russian pilot in March.

item.title: Her Baby Needs Heart Surgery. But She Is Demanding ‘Unvaccinated’ Blood.
item.description: New Zealand’s health service is seeking to take temporary custody of a critically ill infant so it can perform a lifesaving operation.
item.dc:creator: Emanuel Stoakes
item.media:description: The New Zealand health service has denied the family’s request to use blood from unvaccinated volunteers and says that the vaccines pose no risk to donor supplies.

item.title: EU Embargo of Russian Oil and G7’s Price Cap Take Effect
item.description: An immediate impact on oil supplies in Europe was not expected, partly because the embargo has been in the works for months.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: A gas station in Frankfurt, Germany.

item.title: Russia’s Economy Is Threatened by War and Sanctions
item.description: While Russia’s economy has not collapsed, an exodus of Western companies is eroding hard-won progress, and experts say the worst may be yet to come.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: The closed Volkswagen factory in Kaluga, Russia. The slowdown in auto manufacturing is one of the most tangible signs of the effects of Western sanctions on Russia’s economy.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: The Social Cost of ‘Zero Covid’
item.description: Plus, Iran abolishes the morality police and Russia vows to defy an oil price cap.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A lone woman sneaked into an exercise area last month at a park that had been cordoned off by red plastic barriers, near Xiasha Village in Shenzhen, China.

item.title: Werner Franke, Who Exposed East German Doping Program, Dies at 82
item.description: In the 1990s, he and his wife unearthed documentary evidence of the illicit, state-sponsored drug program that propelled the country to Olympic glory.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Dr. Werner Franke at a conference in Germany in 2015. He and his wife exposed the state-sponsored doping program that brought East Germany Olympic glory in the 1970s and ’80s.

item.title: Macron Says Security Guarantees For Russia Are an ‘Essential’ Part of Peace Talks
item.description: Ukraine reacts an
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France during his state visit to the United States on Friday.

item.title: A Strike, Averted
item.description: Congress stepped in to prevent supply chain havoc, but rail workers’ biggest grievance remains unaddressed.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Freight trains in Atlanta.

item.title: Omega X Members Say Their K-pop Agency Mistreated Them
item.description: A public dispute between band members and the head of their agency has revived concerns about whether South Korean entertainment agencies exploit young musicians.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Mike Ives

item.title: China’s Covid Restrictions Collide With Beijing’s Social Contract
item.description: The world’s harshest Covid restrictions exemplify how Xi Jinping’s authoritarian excesses have rewritten Beijing’s longstanding social contract with its people.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A lone woman sneaked into an exercise area last month at a park that had been cordoned off by red plastic barriers, near Xiasha Village in Shenzhen, China.

item.title: The Texas Public Policy Foundation’s National Crusade Against Climate Action
item.description: The Texas Public Policy Foundation is shaping laws, running influence campaigns and taking legal action in a bid to promote fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Montinique Monroe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jason Isaac, director of the Life:Powered initiative of the Texas Public Policy Foundation. “Today, I’m thankful to live a high-carbon lifestyle and wish the rest of the world could too,” he tweeted on Thanksgiving.

item.title: Arab Fans are Confronting Israeli Media at Qatar’s World Cup
item.description: When Qatar granted access to Israeli soccer fans and media despite an absence of diplomatic ties, some saw it as another sign of warming ties with the Arab world. Instead, some of the Israelis got a chilly reception.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Fans of Tunisia cheering with Palestinian flags at the World Cup in Doha, Qatar, last month.

item.title: Kremlin’s Defiance Adds Questions Over Whether Oil Price Cap Will Work
item.description: The Pre
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens, Ivan Nechepurenko and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Deputy Prime Minister of Russia Alexander Novak during the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum in June.

item.title: Rogue Wave Strikes Cruise Ship, Killing One and Injuring 4 Others
item.description: The passengers were hurt after a large, unpredictable wave hit the ship, which was traveling toward the Antarctic, Viking Cruises said.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Tourism to the Antarctic has steadily increased in recent decades, prompting concerns about environmental damage and human safety.

item.title: Why Is Rahul Gandhi Walking 2,000 Miles Across India?
item.description: Rahul Gandhi is hoping to pull his once-mighty party out of the political wilderness. The future of India as a multiparty democracy may be on the line.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Rahul Gandhi marching in the outskirts of Hyderabad, in southern India, early last month. To reach voters, he said, there is “no other way but to hit the streets to listen and connect with people.”

item.title: Ukraine Calls for Evacuations From a Russian-Controlled Area
item.description: A Ukrainian official urged civilians to leave the eastern bank of the Dnipro River, across from the city of Kherson, warning of the “possible intensification of hostilities” there.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Ukrainian billboards on Friday in Kherson, a strategic southern city that Ukrainian forces recently recaptured. Weeks earlier, posters there had pro-Russian messages.

item.title: Your Holiday Rituals
item.description: Rituals make the season meaningful for many of you.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: After Half a Century, Prince Edward Island’s Musical Tradition Takes a Break
item.description: The musical theater version of “Anne of Green Gables,” a favorite of tourists from around the world, will now be staged only every other year.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.category: Anne of Green Gables - The Musical (Play)

item.title: After Fanning Covid Fears, China Must Now Try to Allay Them
item.description: Beijing had long warned that the only effective response was testing, quarantine and lockdowns. As it shifts policy, it must change how it portrays the risks.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: An epidemic control worker in Beijing on Friday cleaning outside a barrier fence in an area with communities in lockdown.

item.title: Photos: Mauna Loa’s Eruption Offers Rare Glimpse Into the Earth
item.description: The world’s largest active volcano erupted for the first time in 38 years, raising excitement among scientists who are eager to unlock its many mysteries.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:description: Mauna Loa, the world’s largest active volcano, began erupting this week for the first time since 1984.

item.title: Landslide Tragedy Turns Italy’s Focus to Illegal Construction
item.description: After 11 deaths, a series of government amnesties for illegally built homes is becoming a focus of a blame game.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters searched for victims this past week after a landslide hit Casamicciola Terme, a port town on the southern Italian island of Ischia.

item.title: He Returned a Dazed Soldier to the Russians. Ukraine Calls It Treason.
item.description: No one knew what to do with a lost Russian pilot who suddenly appeared in the occupied city of Kherson. The case has revealed the blurred line between pragmatism in a war zone and collaboration with the enemy.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Watchmen at the junction in Kherson where they captured a disoriented Russian pilot in March.

item.title: U.S. Sees Little Prospect for Ukraine Talks With Putin After Biden Offer
item.description: The Kremlin reaffirmed a stance that both Washington and Kyiv find unacceptable, and U.S. officials said Mr. Biden’s position had not changed.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Switzerland last year.

item.title: As Macron Loses His Sheen at Home, Harmonious U.S. Visit Is ‘Regenerative’
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron, dealing with a difficult start to his second term, can return to France feeling buoyed by a warm reception and unity on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France greeting people in New Orleans on Friday, where he was reminded of the bargain price of the Louisiana Purchase.

item.title: Zelensky Proposes Banning Ukrainian Orthodox Church Led by Putin Ally
item.description: Ukraine’s president called for legislation to prevent an ancient branch of the Orthodox Church, led by a Putin ally, from operating in his country, but it remains unclear how that would work.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A priest leading a Sunday service at a Russian Orthodox Church in the city of Kryvyi Rih, in Ukraine’s Dnipro region, in October.

item.title: Hans Magnus Enzensberger, Leading Light in German Letters, Dies at 93
item.description: Poet, essayist, journalist and social critic, he held wide influence among a postwar literary generation with works as intellectual as they were political.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Hans Magnus Enzensberger at a political event in Frankfurt in 1968. He was regarded as one of the founding literary figures of the Federal Republic of Germany.

item.title: Pakistan Condemns ‘Assassination Attempt’ on Its Kabul Embassy
item.description: The gunfire, which critically injured one security guard, comes amid increased tensions between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: Taliban security forces in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Friday, near the site of an attack on the Pakistani embassy.

item.title: Canadian Man Charged in Rebecca Contois's Murder Accused of 3 More Killings
item.description: The suspect was accused of killing three Indigenous women and another unidentified woman, all of whom had gone missing in Winnipeg.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: John Woods/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Relatives and friends of three murdered women, including Morgan Harris, gathered at a vigil in Winnipeg.

item.title: Paul Whelan, American Prisoner in Russia, Contacts Family After Weeks of Silence
item.description: Mr. Whelan is serving a 16-year sentence in Russia on espionage charges that the United States calls politically motivated.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Paul Whelan, an American accused by Russian officials of spying, is being held at a penal colony in the Mordovia region of the country.

item.title: How the ‘Price Cap’ on Russian Oil Works
item.description: The plan to curb Moscow’s oil revenues relies heavily on European shipping and insurance companies, but experts point to major loopholes.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: An oil refinery in Omsk, Russia, in November.

item.title: In Call With Putin, Scholz Vows Germany’s Continued Support for Ukraine
item.description: The call, which the Germany chancellery said lasted an hour, was the first between the two leaders since September.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany in Berlin in October.

item.title: Ukrainian Embassies Targeted With Bloody Packages, Kyiv Says
item.description: The packages arrived several days after six letter bombs were mailed to offices in Spain, including those of Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez and the American and Ukrainian Embassies.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Police officers rerouted civilians after a letter bomb blew up in the Ukrainian Embassy in Madrid on Wednesday.

item.title: Population Growth Is Making Hurricanes More Expensive
item.description: The 2022 Atlantic hurricane season, which ended this week, was one of the most destructive on record.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick and Ashley Wu
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Debris and destruction left behind by Hurricane Ian at Fort Meyers Beach, Fla. in October.

item.title: New Zealand and Australia Ponder a Lower Voting Age
item.description: As today’s teenagers will bear the brunt of tomorrow’s problems, especially climate woes, some lawmakers think 16-year-olds deserve a say at the polls.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A polling station in Auckland, New Zealand, in 2020.

item.title: The Drummer Who Reminds People That ‘You Can Play Music as You Like’
item.description: Miguel Tomasín, one of the few professional musicians with Down syndrome, has brought attention to the artistic visions of people with developmental disabilities, with his band releasing over 100 albums.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Anita Pouchard Serra
item.media:credit: Anita Pouchard Serra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Miguel Tomasín has released more than 100 albums with his band, Reynols.

item.title: How a German State Helped Russia Complete Nord Stream 2
item.description: The threat of U.S. sanctions jeopardized completion of a second direct gas pipeline from Russia. So Gazprom and German officials concocted a phony climate foundation to get the job done.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pipes from Nord Stream 2 work in Sassnitz, Germany. Russia invaded Ukraine weeks after the pipeline was finished.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Emmanuel Macron’s state visit to the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Joe Biden and President Emmanuel Macron talk while walking down the Colonnade to the Oval Office at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: As Officials Ease Covid Restrictions, China Faces New Pandemic Risks
item.description: Huge swaths of the nation’s elderly remain vulnerable, scientists say, and a surge in deaths and hospitalizations may be inevitable.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Health care workers on Tuesday in Beijing, where daily Covid numbers have been at their highest since the pandemic began.

item.title: Germans Turn to Heat Pumps to Replace Gas Furnaces
item.description: The boxy machines look and function like large air-conditioners on reverse, but Germans hope they hold the key to Europe’s push for fossil-free heating.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Patrick Junker
item.media:description: A heat pump made by Vaillant, in a special room where the German company tests the device’s electromagnetic radiation.

item.title: Prosecutor Drops Australia Parliament Rape Case, Citing Toll on Accuser
item.description: Mental trauma that Brittany Higgins faced from the proceedings presented a “significant and unacceptable risk” to her life, the prosecutor said.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: The defendant, Bruce Lehrmann, leaving court in Canberra, Australia, in October.

item.title: Day 2: Your Ugly Christmas Sweater Is Beautiful in Its Own Way
item.description: The Times’s fashion director casts a discerning eye on this peculiar holiday tradition.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman

item.title: ‘Constant’ Russian Airstrikes Stifle Ukraine’s Efforts to Restore Power
item.description: Even as Ukrainian workers race to restore basic services like electricity, heat and water, new Russian airstrikes send them back to the starting line.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: During a blackout in Kyiv this week.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Is China Relenting?
item.description: Plus: Kyiv in darkness, South Africa in turmoil and the week in culture.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Vigil attendees in Beijing commemorated the victims of an apartment fire in Urumqi, China.

item.title: Can Neymar and Brazil’s World Cup Team Unite a Fractured Nation?
item.description: Brazil’s World Cup team has become a political lightning rod at home after an ugly election. A championship might be the only thing that can bring Brazil together.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brazilian fans wore the classic yellow team jerseys, but also blue and white variations as they gathered in Rio de Janeiro’s beachside Copacabana neighborhood last week to watch their team’s first game at the World Cup.

item.title: EU Talks Over Russian Oil Price Cap Drag On
item.description: The negotiations over a policy intended to crimp a vital source of revenue for Russia’s war effort have been going on for more than a week.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Inside a Gazprom plant in Omsk, Russia. Ukraine’s allies want to limit Russian oil revenues as much as possible without causing a supply shock.

item.title: Ramaphosa’s Future as South Africa’s Leader in Doubt After Damning Report
item.description: An independent panel reported to Parliament that the South African president might have broken the law in a scandal over a large amount of cash hidden at his game farm that was then stolen.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa, center, in 2019. He swept into office four years ago as a champion of good governance.
